content.description: Climbs some amazing huecos in a crack feature for the first couple of bolts.  A couple of longer moves in the middle lead you to a shared anchor with Pummeled Peter.
content.location: Starts the same as Cargo but goes straight up

content.description:
Begin on top of the large boulder that forms the roof of a small cave right of Meadowbolic. Climb technical moves on good edges to a small roof at halfway. Pull the roof on some big slopers and a perfectly placed left foot on the lip (crux). Relax on big edges to an easy mantel finish.

There is a 4 bolt extension that goes out the massive roof above that continues at 5.12a, but it has nasty fixed draws.
content.location: On top of the large boulder right of Meadowbolic. It's an easy scramble up the left side. Alternatively, you could go in the cave on the right and chimney up to the top.

content.description: Last route on the right side of the! bouldery start leads to a fun dihedral.
Tough and bouldery for the first two bolts. One more long lock off move near the top. Then you're rewarded with easier climbing to the anchor.
content.location: Just to the right of Hey Joe

content.description: Powerful bouldery for the first three bolts. Then easy 5.11 to the shared anchor of 50 year storm. Stick clip the first two bolts so if you fall you don't swing into your belayer.
content.location: Starts just right of 50 year storm.

content.description: Pull through 3 bolts of slopey holds to a rest at the roof. Prepare to get totally “rad” on the unique boulder problem that climbs the face above the roof and clip the chains.
content.location: Climb starts directly left of the “mud heuco” about 200 feet left from where the approach trail meets the wall

content.description: Climbs a lichen cover faced to a slabby finish.  Worth doing even though it's a little dirty.
content.location: Farthest left route on the wall. Shares an anchor with Where are all the warm ups?

content.description: Follow the crack up and enjoy climbing on chicken head edges. An enjoyable warm up.  You can stay left on the arête to gain the ledge with anchors, or do yourself a favor and stay on the bolt line to the ledge.  Maybe makes this a 5.9?
content.location: On the right side, The cliff breaks and perhaps 100 yards from the previous cliff-line you reach another buttress.

content.description: Techy climbing for most of the route.  Climbs way better than it looks.
content.location: Next sport route right of Last Call.

content.description: A bouldery start on some smaller holds leads to some easy slab climbing, and then a steeper finish on good holds.
Climb the technical face to the right of P.T. Fairly sustained with a defined crux. Beautiful movement! The book says that this route stays dry in the rain.
content.location: To the right of P.T., just left of the boulder ledge.

content.description: Route just right of betty bravo. Start up a vertical to the second bolt. Move left and up around a blank section to the third bolt. From here climb to and pull the low roof. A powerful lockoff guards the thin slab above.
content.location: Just right of the obvious Betty Bravo line. Left most of the cliff bands

content.description: Start in a shallow dihedral in an obvious weakness. Traverse right about 20 feet in a good horizontal to a stance before a blank section. A cool balance move gets you across the blankness with a small pocket. The book says "it's crucial to have a TCU with a narrow head to fit the pocket". Goat climb past a bolt to a large sloping ledge. Then climb past 3 closely spaced bolts on smaller edges and tougher moves to anchors below the large roof.
content.location: 20 feet right of the small cave past Meadowbolic and Velocacrimper. Starts in a small dihedral.

content.description: Link Cinco de Mitcho into Growing Pains by clipping a double length runner to the fifth bolt and traversing to the right bolt line.
content.location: Walk left from Betty Bravo for 2 minutes until the cliff picks back up. Start on the line of white bolts to the left of a large right facing flake.

content.description: Sustained climbing for the first 4 bolts! A long move going by the 4th bolt leads to easy climbing to the little roof. A couple of crimps getting through the roof then easier climbing for the rest of the route.
content.location: Right of Roper's Rebate.

content.description:
Really nice trad route that feels like a sport climb. Similar to the other routes on this wall, get through the start and you should have the send. A couple of tricky moves getting into the crack at the top, but there are plenty of face holds to keep it at a reasonable difficulty.

A two bolt start protects the intro crux moves, one bolt above the roof. The rest of the route is well protected.
content.location: Immediately right of Me Too 5.11b. Look for a large crack on the upper head wall after the roof. Start in a black streak with two bolts.

content.description: Relatively easy start up a low angle slab. Easy moves to a no hands rest at the third bolt. Move slightly right around a blunt arete for some awesome pre-crux moves. Get to two iron pockets below a blank white face. Execute a "surreal crux" on some small edges. Climb easier ground on good flat edges and the occasional jug for a few bolts, navigate a roof then tech to the top on slightly dirty terrain.
content.location: Around the corner right of Little Pocket on a steep dirt and root hill.

content.description: This route has several cruxes. The toughest of the cruxes is getting past the last bolt. Definitely classic mud hueco climbing edges, pockets and good jug rests.
content.location: The next sport route to the right of Me Too. There is a mixed line in between the two routes

content.description: Take chances, make mistakes. That's how you grow. Start on the enormous right facing flake and follow the bolt line straight up out the roof through the water runnel on headwall.  The holds on this climb belong in a museum.
content.location: Head left of Betty Bravo for two minutes until the cliffline picks back up.  This is the first route on the right side of the wall, starting on a large right facing flake.

content.description: Starts left of bac! Follow the face to the corner system out the roof and up the face.

Stick clip the first bolt then boulder out the low roof. Good core tension ends with a snap to a crimp and a sloper. Slight traverse right to a hueco and a big undercling stand up move leads you to the second bolt. The climbing eases from here but sill involves long reaches between great holds. Varied rock goes from typical NRG huecos and slopers to classic RRG iron bands. At the top, move slightly right of the dihedral to the face and race to the chains.

If you stick the boulder problem to the 2nd bolt, the send is yours
content.location: Obvious route that starts under a low roof on good holds. About 75 yrds to the left of the mud hueco. just right of ropers rebate 13a

climbs.name: Cold Steel
climbs.fa: Andy Johnson, Bolted by Lee Munson

content.description: Easy face climbing to the roof. Good holds through the roof lead to a dead point off of small crimps to a slot.  Named due to the 0.5 by 12 inch cold steel bolt in the roof.
content.location: This route is just left of the Radness.

content.description: No filler climbing on this one, folks. Start with a powerful boulder, tech your way through the slab, then make a large gymnastic move that will put a smile on your face.
content.protection: 7 bolts + Bolt Anchor w/ Lower Offs
content.location: Walk on the trail left of Betty Bravo for 2 minutes until the cliff picks back up. The first bolt on this climb is painted white. Start right of the large right facing flake on a small right hand crimp.

content.description: Starts on the far left  end of the wall. Good holds all the way; climbs up and left. The last half is a little dirty but the good holds are clean.
content.location: Farthest route left

content.description: Start on "Where are the Warm Ups?" and traverse right, beginning the climb with a short-lived boulder problem at the first bolt. Easy climbing over the small roof takes you up to a crimp/undercling crux between the 4th and 5th bolts. Typical Meadow River glory moves take you to the chains.
content.location: Just left of Betty Bravo.

content.description: Start on a large right facing flake, gain the slab after clipping the third bolt, and traverse left at the break to the fourth bolt. Make a long move through the blank powerband to your choice of slotted crimps. Fun climbing to the chains through bullet stone.
content.location: To the left of the main area following the cliff breakdown. Starts approx. 30 feet right of Humble Beginnings on a large right facing flake.

content.description: Climb the face on interesting rock to the first roof. Get set on an jug rail and classic NRG long lock off. Continue on long moves on good rock with an interesting balance move up high on the slab.
content.location: On the far right end of the cliff line. A prominent 2 finger pocket is just above the first bolt

content.description: Stick clip and climb the dihedral and steep roof.  Thin holds exiting the steep section leads to easier climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Starts basically where the trail meets the cliff line. Has some fixed gear on it.

content.description: Starts on pummeled peter, but goes straight up.  Crimpy crux leads to easier climbing out the top.
content.location: in between pummeled peter and where all all the warm ups.

content.description: The first 4 bolts are pretty intense! Small holds big moves and powerful.  Pull the first roof and enjoy easier climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Starts just right of B.A.C.
